title: 107_hr1948
content: The Act titled "Medical Laboratory Personnel Shortage Act of 2001" addresses the shortage of medical laboratory personnel and establishes programs under the Health Resources and Services Administration to respond to this issue. The Act "Medical Laboratory Personnel Shortage Act of 2001" addresses the shortage of medical laboratory personnel by amending the National Health Service Corps Scholarship and Loan Repayment Programs to include medical technologists and medical laboratory technicians. The Act "Medical Laboratory Personnel Shortage Act of 2001" amends the Public Health Service Act to give preference in making awards to assist entities in expanding programs to increase the number of individuals trained as medical laboratory personnel. The Act "Medical Laboratory Personnel Shortage Act of 2001" amends the Public Health Service Act to authorize appropriations for allied health and other disciplines, as well as for medical laboratory personnel training programs. Authorized appropriations are made for awards of grants or contracts to schools of allied health under sections 737 through 739. This includes $11,193,000 for fiscal year 2002 for awards to schools, $332,500 for fiscal year 2002 for faculty awards, and $8,200,000 for fiscal year 2002 for awards to schools. Additional funding is also available for each fiscal year from 2003 through 2006. The term 'medical laboratory personnel' is defined as allied health professionals who examine materials from the human body for diagnostic purposes. SEC. 3. RESPONSE TO SHORTAGE OF MEDICAL LABORATORY PERSONNEL; PROGRAMS OF CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. Amends Title XV of the Public Health Service Act to address the shortage of technologists for laboratory analysis related to screening for cervical cancer. The Secretary will make grants to entities for training cytotechnologists to screen women for cervical cancer. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2002, with additional funding for 2003-2006 if needed. The Public Health Service Act is amended to support programs training medical laboratory personnel in recognizing pathogen resistance. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include training programs for medical laboratory personnel in disciplines that recognize or identify pathogens. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include training programs for medical laboratory personnel in disciplines that recognize or identify potential biological agents. The Public Health Service Act is amended to include training programs for medical laboratory personnel, with emphasis on disciplines needing more personnel.
